description.plain:
OneRepublic is an American pop rock band, led by Ryan Tedder.

The band has released four studio albums, Dreaming Out Loud (2007), Waking Up (2009) and Native (2013), and Oh My My (2016). “Apologize” and “Counting Stars” are two of their most well-known singles, the former being their debut and the latter from the third album.

The band started with the name “Republic,” but then it was changed to “OneRepublic” or else it would be difficult to distinguish the group from other bands and other search items on search engines.

Before signing to Mosley Music Group under Interscope Records, the band was signed to Columbia Records. They were working on their debut album with “Sleep” as the lead single when Columbia Records dropped the group two months before the release.

The band then became the top unsigned act on MySpace and caught Timbaland’s attention. After the release of their debut album Dreaming Out Loud with the original version of “Apologize” as the lead single, the remix version by Timbaland released on his compilation album Shock Value became a massive hit nationally and globally.

description.plain:
“Kids” is the second single from OneRepublic’s fourth studio album, Oh My My. The lyrics premiered on Genius on Aug. 11, 2016, and the song’s audio was released globally on Aug. 12.

“Kids” is the follow-up to OneRepublic’s lead single, “Wherever I Go.”

description.plain:
“Apologize” is the debut single of OneRepublic.
The original version of the track was released on their debut album Dreaming Out Loud (2007), but it wasn’t until Timbaland remixed the track and released it with OneRepublic as the featured artist on his own compilation album Shock Value that the band and the track received attention from the mass.

Timbaland’s remix version became a massive national and global hit and set the record of the biggest radio airplay hit in the history of the Mainstream Top 40 chart in North America, with 10,394 plays in one week, until its record was broken by Leona Lewis’s “Bleeding Love”.

“Apologize” remained OneRepublic’s most successful single, until 2013’s “Counting Stars” from the album Native.

description.plain:
OneRepublic’s second standalone-single of 2018, this song is unusually short – at two and a half minutes – yet lyrically dense, with a modern hip-hop influenced style.

Ryan Tedder here voices the universal, innate human longing for meaningful companionship. This song presents the flip side of 1R’s 2016 song A.I.; whereas in A.I. Ryan is afraid of having a real relationship – “I just want my love automatic” – here he is desperately seeking one.

The word “connection” in this modern technological world usually refers to an internet connection, not often a human one, which adds a touch of irony to Ryan’s plea. These days everyone is connected to so many different things: phones, laptops, TV’s, Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat – but no one’s actually bothering to connect to each other, personally, face to face. It has been scientifically shown that the more “connected” we are to social media and electronics, the more likely we are to be depressed or lonely.

Ryan Tedder has previously expressed his intentions of making more serious, socially aware songs. In an interview with the German magazine Schön around August 2017, he said:

It’s critical to shed light on social problems. I’m doing my best to address issues that people are thinking about, issues that are real. People’s obsession with staring at their phones and living their lives through other people’s Instagram pages and feeling depressed about… their life… because they don’t have the same figure or the same money – that’s an issue and it’s one that more people should be writing about.

This is also a very personal song for Ryan and the band, as it reflects his own journey through life. Ryan’s life had become so hectic and hustle filled that by early 2016, shortly after the release of 1R’s fourth album Oh My My, he had to let his entire musical career come to a stop for many months to rest and reconnect with his wife and kids, who he was often away from for long periods of time on business. Even though he was doing what he loves, it was just too much. This song echoes that long pause to rediscover the truly important things in life.

description.plain:
“I Lived” is the fifth track on Native. It was also the last song covered on the Fox comedy-drama, Glee.

Frontman Ryan Tedder has stated in an interview with Radio.com that nothing on the album is fiction; these songs are based on personal experiences.

“I Lived” is a love letter dedicated to Ryan’s son, Copeland Cruz, who was born August 2nd, 2010.



gif source

You know, it’s like a wish for somebody. Like, I wish this for you, I wish that for you.

description.plain:
“Rescue Me” is the fast-paced, straightforward single off of 1R5, where Ryan Tedder delves deeper into the album’s major theme as developed in earlier 1R5 releases, like “Connection” and  “Wanted”. Thematically, the song depicts the vital importance of a sincere relationship to human well-being.

“Rescue Me” shares a common message with their 2016 track “Lift Me Up”:

If I told you I was down, I was down would you help me?
Told you I was down, I was down would you lift me up?
I need your strength, I’ll be up someday
If I told you I was down, I was down would you lift me up?

In an interview with Celebmix, Ryan describes the song’s creation as being spontaneous:

“Rescue Me” was written very quickly, 10 minutes or less almost a stream of consciousness. It was me telling Brent, our bass player and cellist, “I wanna write a song with a concept I had started a few years ago (called “Rescue Me”).”  He started playing this lonely sounding guitar riff and the first thing out of my mouth was the chorus as it is now.

description.plain:
“No Vacancy” is a song with summer vibes about being completed and uplifted by a new person in the singer’s life.

It was released after the band took a 4 month break and a few minutes before sharing a post explaining its future. In it, OneRepublic stated that they will be releasing songs they like without worrying about making full albums with a specific sound.

In an interview with Billboard Ryan has described No Vacancy as one of his most pop type of works.

I’ve thrown all the rules out – if a song feels good and if my two-year-old kid requests it every single day for a month, it’s probably a good song. “No Vacancy” is pretty much coming out because my kids have requested it pretty much every day for the last three months.
It’s the poppiest thing we’ve ever done – I struggled with it at first. I was like, “Man, this is so pop, maybe I should give it to somebody else.”…
I wrote it thinking about my kids – you have all the space in your life and then you have kids, and that last little hole that you have in your life is completely full. The concept, to me, came from such an internal place that I was like, “You know what? I don’t care if this is the poppiest thing we’ve ever done. It feels good, and I want to roll with it.” For the first time ever, I’m embracing the idea of pop and going all the way with it.

description.plain:
“Wherever I Go”, OneRepublic’s first single off of Oh My My, sounds like nothing the band has produced before, says frontman, Ryan Tedder:

 It’s not indicative of the entire album but it’s kind of like if you go have dinner, you don’t order steak for an appetizer and steak for dinner, you split it up, and you have different things, so the first single is – it’s definitely an appetizer, I think it’s the best appetizer we could come up with.

Ryan Tedder stated that it was the hardest song for from to write and took the longest time to finish for Oh My My. https://twitter.com/OneRepublic/status/784431472149090304

description.plain:
“Love Runs Out” was intended to be the first single off the album, Native.

In a concert in Amsterdam, he mentioned that they put it off because he could not finish it since you can’t have a song without a chorus.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kjr_aBSG3HA

It wasn’t until Brent Kutzle, bassist and cellist of OneRepublic, mentioned the song again to Ryan in the beginning of the year that they began working on it again.

You can find the song on the reissue of Native on iTunes and in stores.

description.plain:
“Good Life” was released as the fourth single from OneRepublic’s sophomore album, Waking Up. This uplifting track focuses on themes of optimism and contentment, which is reflective of their previous work and became a focal point of their next album.

Brent Kutzle composed the song in a single night after the album was already completed. Brent had decided to work on something that night before Ryan Tedder left the studio and asked him what should he be working on; Ryan told him to just let go of everything and make something which makes you feel good. Afterwards, Brent wrote this song that was related to the emotion he was feeling at the time.

In a show at Troubadour, Ryan Tedder talks about some of the greatest pieces of music we’ve ever known and love were written in only a couple of hours, with real feelings without considering chord progression; in the same manner was how “Good Life” was written.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TxEwi3e_rho

description.plain:
This song has a colorful history: Ryan Tedder first started singing it live in the summer of 2018, with lyrics slightly different from the final version. OneRepublic waited over a year before they actually released “Wanted”, teasing it by filming several different recording sessions and live performances with it on the Netflix behind the scenes music show Once In a Lifetime Sessions.

Lyrically, it follows the theme of the entire album, exploring the universal human need for meaningful companionship and bonding.

description.plain: This song is self-depreciating. It is the band joking about doubt they’ve received from critics. The critics have a powerful influence over consumers, hence, all the right friends, all the right moves. The band is sort of mocking the critics who told them they were going to fail at music, hence, we’re going down. Are we just sinking in the ocean of faces? This is asking the consumers if they stand out or if they are just another typical wannabe. Around that term, they are asking the consumers if they think the band is good enough to make it in music industry.

description.plain:
This song was OneRepublic’s second big hit, and it marked a crucial, “make it or break it” moment in their history, as recounted in the mini-documentary Don’t Look Down. Would “Apologize” be their first and only success? Would OneRepublic be known as a one-hit wonder, or as a band capable of making popular music? “Stop and Stare” ended this uncertainty when it became a successful song, and OneRepublic continued to make music for a way wider group of devoted fans.

The song is principally based on the idea of feeling lost or trapped: you’re in a position where the world seems to have gone crazy, and you feel like you can’t get out of this rut that you’re in. However, towards the end of the song, a more positive message is addressed: if you believe hard enough in what you’re doing, you can make it in every case, whatever you choose to do in order to improve yourself in the future.

description.plain:
“Somebody to Love” is OneRepublic’s chosen song from the show “Songland” with their episode being the Season 1 finale that aired on September 11, 2019 on NBC. The songwriter who presented this to OneRepublic was JT Roach.

Ryan Tedder and the band performed this song at their 2019 concerts at the Red Rocks Amphitheater featuring the Colorado Symphony (both on August 27th and 28th) before this song officially released.

description.plain:
“Better” has a very different sound from OneRepublic’s regular sound. This song contains a beat and vocal effects reminiscent of Twenty One Pilots consisting of bass, electric drums, synthesizers, and almost “rap-singing” style vocals.

The lyrics suggest a theme of anxiety and explore the difficulty of having a mental illness, but they have a strong hopeful element as well.

description.plain:
“Human” is centered around the concept of someone who’s lost touch with God turning to Him only during a bad experience, with God in return trying to sympathize with their pain.

In response to the person, God asks how it feels to be “Human,” almost as if He doesn’t genuinely know due to Jesus being the Son and human embodiment of God.

With all of the band members being Christians, Tedder said on Twitter that he thought the song would be risky, even sacrilegious. However, with Kutzle’s father being a pastor, he looked into Scripture, and gave the song the all go.

https://twitter.com/OneRepublic/status/784440676536684544

The album was actually entitled “Human” at one point, which would have been even more convenient since the album was created to encompass the human experience.

description.plain:
This is the 11th track out of OneRepublic’s 2013 album Native and talks about lead singer Ryan Tedder’s late grandfather, who really was a preacher and was like a guide to Ryan when he was younger.
It was recorded in New Orleans with local African-American backup singers to lend a unique gospel sound. Ryan Tedder was raised in a large Christian family and has a deep understanding of gospel music.

description.plain:
“Feel Again” is the lead single for Native.

Part of the earnings of the song will be donated to Save the Children’s Every Beat Matters campaign.

The song could be about someone who can’t feel anything after trying to fix his previous relationship that’s already been dead, the result of his own mistakes, and is romantically lost but later is able to “feel again” when he finds a new love.

description.plain:
Written from the perspective of Mother Earth, that is talking to her inhabitants, as a call to action against climate change.

“I wanted to take a break from writing songs about myself,” says Tedder. “So, I took the point-of-view of Mother Earth turning the tables on those who’d betray her.”

description.plain:
“Au Revoir is the ninth track on the band’s third album "Native”. While tracks on the albums were recorded in various studios around the world, “Au Revoir” was recorded in a studio in France.

“Au revoir” is “goodbye” in French. Ryan Tedder, the lead vocalist and main songwriter of the band, learnt the French expression when working in a studio in France for some tracks on their 3rd album “Native”. The newly acquired knowledge inspired the title of this track.

description.plain:
The 14th or 15th song (depending on how you count the bonus tracks) off of OneRepublic’s third studio album, Native.
A cheerful, exuberant, upbeat song about having a healthy perspective on life.
The theme covers living life to the fullest, embracing all parts of it, the happy times as well as the difficult times. Often we need the pain in life to a certain extent to help us truly appreciate the good. A fine painting uses both light and dark colors, and music is made up of combinations of notes suspended in silence.
And oftentimes just when we think all is lost, things start to get better. As Ryan Tedder says in the other bonus track on this album, “something’s gotta give.”

Also, life is easier to handle when you have a faithful companion, as Ryan describes in the second verse; the old saying goes “a good friend doubles your joys and halves your sorrows.”

“Life In Color” has been used in Ralph Lauren advertisements.

There is a live acoustic performance of this which is much slower and more soulfully rendered than the studio version; Ryan’s voice is almost tearful, giving the words an unexpected “beauty in brokenness” feel which is quite remarkable.

https://youtu.be/Ytc7IxU9kq8

Often we need the pain in life to a certain extent to help us truly appreciate the good. A fine painting uses both light and dark colors, and music is made up of combinations of notes suspended in silence.
And oftentimes just when we think all is lost, things start to get better. As Ryan Tedder says in the other bonus track on this album, “something’s gotta give.”

Also, life is easier to handle when you have a faithful companion, as Ryan describes in the second verse; the old saying goes “a good friend doubles your joys and halves your sorrows.”

“Life In Color” has been used in Ralph Lauren advertisements.

There is a live acoustic performance of this which is much slower and more soulfully rendered than the studio version; Ryan’s voice is almost tearful, giving the words an unexpected “beauty in brokenness” feel which is quite remarkable.

https://youtu.be/Ytc7IxU9kq8

description.plain:
This song stands in bright contrast to OneRepublic’s more well-known works such as “Counting Stars” or “Apologize.”
  With a noisy rock and roll electric guitar riff, vocals reminiscent of Led Zeppelin, and some cryptic lyrics, Ryan Tedder pays homage to the rowdy rock music of the seventies or eighties.

The title itself often refers to lighting up something to smoke, but in this context the phrase has a playful double, or maybe even triple, meaning. Ryan is saying he can light up her life and bring fun and excitement into it. Eyes can also light up, with love, delight, laughter, etc. The lyrics are also rife with things to light up like “a million drums of kerosene.”
Ryan uses this unusual language metaphorically as a harmless symbol of good times and adventure, adapting the characteristics of classic rock music that some people object to – the drug culture, the harsh electric sound – into something of this time.
The metaphor is brought clearly into focus when he says he’s “acting like your favorite drug.”

description.plain:
This song is a live rendition of Timbaland’s 2007 song “Apologize”, featuring OneRepublic. It also has a bridge consisting of an elongated chorus from Sam Smith’s 2014 song “Stay With Me”.

It was performed at the 2015 Pinkpop Festival, an annual music festival held in the Netherlands. It is the oldest running festival dedicated to pop and rock music.

description.plain:
This is a fast-paced, energetic song, released by OneRepublic for a video game titled Need For Speed.
The song only officially came out in some parts of Asia. Born To Race never released in Europe.

Ryan Tedder here is singing about action and accomplishment. He moves past the naysayers and brushes off those who would try to hold him back.
He seems to relish the tension and thrives on the pressure of being “born to race.”

Ryan has real personal experience with this, as his own life is filled with constant and varied activity ranging from live performances across the globe to writing and producing everything for his own band OneRepublic to collaborating with others to write and produce songs for them, such as Ed Sheeran’s “Happier.” And just think of the many hours spent practicing, rehearsing and honing his skills. (A voice like his doesn’t come easy.)

In fact, Ryan has such a hectic lifestyle that at one point, shortly after the release of OneRepublic’s 4th studio album Oh My My in early 2016, he had to let everything drop or risk having a nervous breakdown from sheer exhaustion.

By early 2017, however, Ryan had resumed his usual activities and is currently working on a multitude of projects.
Ryan Tedder can say with all sincerity “I’m going faster than I ever been.”

description.plain:
Ryan Tedder here takes on the persona of one who has suffered the loss of a close friend or family member through a serious upheaval or natural disaster. He goes through the stages of grief – anger, denial, guilt, questioning, acceptance –  and relives past emotions in a way similar to symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder.

Interestingly this song lacks a chorus, having only certain repeating words and phrases that lend an atmosphere of tension and mystery.

For live performances, Ryan leaves off the second half of the song, and here in this particular rendition, he changes some of the words, perhaps to make it easier to understand for a general audience or to lighten the mood since concerts should have a minimum of sadness.

description.plain:
One of four deluxe edition bonus tracks on their 2009 album Waking Up, this speaks of fidelity and putting your loved one ahead of yourself.

The name is not as strange as it first seems. The definition of a sucker punch is “an unexpected blow” – emphasis on unexpected. Since Ryan Tedder says “I’m aware of my fate, too late,” it seems to mean he’s fallen in love suddenly and without quite meaning to, and then the rest of the song is about his surrender to building his life around this all consuming love.

The chorus reflects the timeless Christian principles of dying to self and putting the interests of others first. After all is said and done, he is not the one who runs his life and calls the shots. In one sense, she is the one; in a grander sense, God is the one.

Ryan is good at incorporating subtle religious ideas into his songs – mainly what he writes for his own band – because of growing up in a devout Pentecostal household with many relatives being missionaries and a grandfather who pastored a church.

description.plain:
This song is called “Trapt Door” on their 2007 album (Dreaming Out Loud) and “Trap Door” on the 2009 album. (Waking Up.) Both are bonus releases, and both are the same song.

Ryan Tedder often approaches songwriting from the perspective of being in a position to offer advice or help to the one he’s speaking with. Songs like “All Fall Down,” “Say (All I Need),” “Someone To Save You,” and “Something’s Not Right Here” fall into this category – coincidentally, these are all from the Dreaming Out Loud album. This song also is in this group, as Ryan is offering his listener a break from her false friends and overcomplicated relationships.

The idea of a trap door is that of an escape route, a secret exit from difficulty that leads to another place.
The Trojan horse draws from the ancient Greek myth of Helen of Troy; after a long and unsuccessful war, the invading army pretended to leave, but they were really hidden inside a giant wooden horse which was left behind. When the townspeople brought the horse within the walls of the city, they unwittingly brought in the enemy soldiers inside it.
The modern definition of a Trojan horse is “ any trick or stratagem that causes a target to invite a foe into a securely protected bastion or place.” (Wikipedia)

description.plain:
A bonus track only available from Target on OneRepublic’s debut album, Dreaming Out Loud, this song addresses the issue of gossipers and naysayers getting in the way of a relationship.

The voices singer Ryan Tedder hears are not in his head; they are the voices of friends and relatives, both his and hers, telling him that he should leave, that things aren’t working out between them, trying to put thoughts in his head and discourage him.
He remains steadfast in his determination to stay, however, reassuring his worried girlfriend that he isn’t leaving, even though things aren’t always easy between them.
He hears the constant, nagging voices, but he refuses to listen to them and break it up.

description.plain:
This version, released over the 2019 American Independence Day weekend, eliminates the original’s danceable electronic beat and focuses on the guitar line and other organic sounds.

Ryan Tedder has described in an interview how quickly the lyrics were written and what the song is about:

‘Rescue Me’ was written very quickly, 10 minutes or less almost a stream of consciousness,“ Tedder said in a release. "It was me telling Brent, our bass player and cellist, ‘I wanna write a song with a concept I had started a few years ago (called ‘Rescue Me’). He started playing this lonely sounding guitar riff and the first thing out of my mouth was the chorus as it is now. The concept: in every friendship, there’s a give and take, but sometimes you have to wonder if the love you give is the love you’ll get.”

description.plain:
The original song is “Say (All I need)”. Here is a version of the song named “Say (à l'infini)”  featuring the french R&B singer Sheryfa Luna.

Ryan Tedder (lead singer of the band) explains the meaning of the song, he said that : “This song is about being happy with what you have in life, and not obsessing over what you don’t have. Whether it’s a person or relationship, love, or success, or even fame.”
One Republic wanted “to make a piece of art and do something beautiful and inspiring”.

description.plain:
Billboard describes this remix in glowing terms:

It’s summer song season, and Michael Brun is tailor-made for sunshine. His Haitian roots give him the upper hand. His heart beats to a tropical rhythm, and his blood runs warm all year round. His take on the summer sound is far from the typical. It’s not clichéd or obvious, it’s just fun and inviting, and he brings that smartness to his remix of OneRepublic’s “Lift Me Up.”

He draws out the song’s danceability with Caribbean bounce and brigtens the melody with island textures. His take is inspiring. OneRepublic singer Ryan Tedder just had to hop into the studio with him to add a bit of his own flair to the production. Brun’s spin was upgraded to official remix.
